name: E&M with Procedure - Modifier 25 Required
description: When an E&M service is performed on the same day as a procedure, modifier 25 must be appended to the E&M code to indicate a significant, separately identifiable service.
clinicalRationale: Modifier 25 is necessary to differentiate an evaluation and management service from the procedure's inherent pre-operative and post-operative work. Without this modifier, the E&M is assumed to be part of the procedure's global service.
commonMistake: Providers bill E&M codes on the same day as procedures without adding modifier 25, causing automatic denials.
fixGuidance: Add modifier 25 to the E&M code when performed on the same day as a procedure to indicate a significant, separately identifiable service.

name: Duplicate Claims - Same Service Same Day
description: Multiple claims for the same procedure code on the same date of service for the same patient will be denied as duplicates unless proper modifiers are used.
clinicalRationale: Duplicate claim edits prevent incorrect payment for services already reimbursed. Legitimate duplicate services require documentation and appropriate modifiers to indicate they were separately performed.
commonMistake: Submitting multiple claims for the same lab test without proper justification or modifiers.
fixGuidance: Use modifier 91 for repeat clinical diagnostic laboratory tests or verify that the claims are not actually duplicates.

name: Medical Necessity - Routine Screening Limits
description: Routine screening procedures are subject to frequency limitations. Claims exceeding allowed frequency will be denied unless medical necessity is documented.
clinicalRationale: Frequency limitations are based on clinical evidence and ensure appropriate utilization of screening services. More frequent testing requires medical justification beyond routine screening.
commonMistake: Ordering routine tests more frequently than coverage policy allows without proper diagnosis codes indicating medical necessity.
fixGuidance: Ensure proper diagnosis codes are included that support medical necessity, or verify frequency limits before ordering.

name: Bilateral Procedure Modifier 50 Required
description: When a bilateral procedure is performed, modifier 50 must be appended or the procedure must be submitted on two lines with modifiers RT/LT.
clinicalRationale: Bilateral modifiers indicate that the same procedure was performed on both sides of the body, warranting additional reimbursement for the extra work and time involved.
commonMistake: Billing bilateral procedures without proper bilateral modifiers, resulting in payment for only one side.
fixGuidance: Add modifier 50 for bilateral procedures, or bill on separate lines with RT (right) and LT (left) modifiers.

name: Place of Service Mismatch
description: Certain procedures are only covered when performed in specific places of service. Claims with incorrect POS codes will be denied.
clinicalRationale: Place of service codes ensure proper payment rates and verify that services were performed in appropriate settings based on medical necessity and safety standards.
commonMistake: Using office visit codes (POS 11) when service was actually performed in a different setting.
fixGuidance: Verify the actual place of service and use the correct POS code that matches where the service was performed.

name: EKG Interpretation - Separate Physician Required
description: Professional component of EKG interpretation can only be billed when performed and documented by a qualified physician.
clinicalRationale: The professional component represents the physician's interpretation and reporting of the EKG findings. This requires specific qualifications and must be separately documented to warrant billing.
commonMistake: Billing for professional interpretation when only technical component was performed, or missing required documentation.
fixGuidance: Ensure proper documentation of physician interpretation and use correct component codes (TC/26) as appropriate.

name: DME Prior Authorization Required
description: Certain durable medical equipment items require prior authorization before coverage will be approved.
clinicalRationale: Prior authorization ensures medical necessity and appropriate use of high-cost DME items, preventing waste and ensuring compliance with coverage criteria.
commonMistake: Ordering DME without obtaining required prior authorization.
fixGuidance: Submit prior authorization request with supporting documentation before ordering covered DME items.

name: Units Exceed Maximum Allowed
description: Claims with units exceeding the maximum allowable per day or per service will be denied or downcoded.
clinicalRationale: Unit limitations are based on clinical appropriateness and time constraints. Exceeding limits requires documentation of medical necessity and exceptional circumstances.
commonMistake: Billing more units than medically necessary or allowed per policy without proper documentation.
fixGuidance: Verify unit limits per policy and ensure documentation supports the number of units billed.

name: Missing or Invalid Diagnosis Code
description: Claims must include valid ICD-10 diagnosis codes that support medical necessity for the services provided.
clinicalRationale: Valid diagnosis codes are essential for establishing medical necessity and ensuring appropriate payment. Invalid or non-specific codes prevent accurate claim adjudication.
commonMistake: Using outdated, invalid, or non-specific diagnosis codes that don't support the service.
fixGuidance: Use current, valid, and specific ICD-10 codes that accurately reflect the patient's condition and support medical necessity.

name: Age Restriction - Screening Not Covered
description: Certain screening procedures have age restrictions and will be denied if patient age falls outside the covered range.
clinicalRationale: Age-based coverage criteria are established based on clinical guidelines and evidence-based recommendations for preventive screenings.
commonMistake: Ordering preventive screening tests for patients outside the approved age range.
fixGuidance: Verify patient age meets policy requirements or use appropriate diagnosis codes if screening is medically necessary despite age.

name: Modifier 59 - Distinct Procedural Service
description: When reporting procedures that would normally be bundled, modifier 59 indicates that the service was distinct and separately identifiable.
clinicalRationale: Modifier 59 should only be used when no other more specific modifier applies. It indicates the service was separate from other services on the same date, performed at a different site, or was a distinct independent procedure.
commonMistake: Overusing modifier 59 for bundled services that don't qualify as distinct, or using it when more specific X-modifiers should be used.
fixGuidance: Use modifier 59 only when services are truly separate and distinct. Consider using X-modifiers (XE, XS, XP, XU) when they more accurately describe the circumstance.

name: Unbundling - Code Combination Not Allowed
description: Certain procedure code combinations are not allowed to be billed together as they represent components of a more comprehensive service.
clinicalRationale: NCCI edits prevent unbundling of services that are inherently part of a more comprehensive procedure. Billing component codes separately constitutes improper coding.
commonMistake: Billing venipuncture separately when it's included in the payment for lab services, or billing minor procedures with E&M without proper separation.
fixGuidance: Use comprehensive codes that include all components of the service performed. Review NCCI edits before submitting claims.

name: Telehealth - Originating Site Requirements
description: Telehealth services have specific requirements for the originating site and patient location. Claims not meeting these criteria will be denied.
clinicalRationale: Telehealth originating site requirements ensure appropriate use of remote services and compliance with Medicare coverage rules for virtual care delivery.
commonMistake: Billing telehealth from non-approved originating sites or using incorrect place of service codes.
fixGuidance: Verify the originating site meets Medicare requirements and use POS code 02 (telehealth) with appropriate modifiers.

name: Preventive Visit with Problem-Focused E&M
description: When a preventive visit includes significant problem-focused evaluation, both services may be billed with appropriate modifiers and documentation.
clinicalRationale: A preventive visit focuses on health screening and counseling, while a problem-focused E&M addresses acute or chronic conditions. When both occur in the same encounter, separate billing requires distinct documentation.
commonMistake: Billing both preventive and problem-focused E&M without modifier 25 on the problem-focused visit, or without sufficient documentation of distinct services.
fixGuidance: Add modifier 25 to the problem-focused E&M code and ensure documentation clearly separates the preventive and problem-focused components.

name: Global Surgical Package - Post-Op Visits
description: Post-operative visits within the global period are included in the surgical fee and cannot be billed separately unless unrelated to the surgery.
clinicalRationale: The global surgical package includes pre-operative, intra-operative, and typical post-operative care for a defined period. Separate billing during this period requires documentation that the service was unrelated to the surgery.
commonMistake: Billing E&M services during the global period without modifier 24 to indicate the service was unrelated to the surgery.
fixGuidance: Use modifier 24 when billing E&M services during the post-operative period for unrelated conditions, with separate diagnosis codes.

name: Psychiatric Services - Same Day Restrictions
description: Certain combinations of psychiatric services cannot be billed on the same day unless clinical circumstances warrant separate sessions.
clinicalRationale: Same-day psychiatric service restrictions prevent inappropriate billing of services that should be combined into a single comprehensive session unless clinical circumstances clearly warrant separate encounters.
commonMistake: Billing multiple psychotherapy sessions on the same day without documentation of separate, distinct sessions with break periods.
fixGuidance: Document separate sessions with distinct start/stop times and breaks between sessions when billing multiple psychotherapy codes on the same day.

name: Incident-To Services - Supervision Requirements
description: Services provided by non-physician practitioners billed incident-to a physician require direct supervision and specific documentation requirements.
clinicalRationale: Incident-to billing allows services by non-physician practitioners to be reimbursed at the physician rate when appropriate supervision is documented. Without proper supervision, services must be billed under the practitioner's own NPI.
commonMistake: Billing incident-to when the physician is not in the office suite or for new problems not previously seen by the physician.
fixGuidance: Ensure the physician is in the office suite and available for immediate assistance. Initial visits and new problems must be seen by the physician first.

name: Observation vs Inpatient Status
description: Claims must accurately reflect whether a patient was under observation or admitted as an inpatient, as this affects coverage and payment.
clinicalRationale: The distinction between observation and inpatient status is based on the expected duration and intensity of care needed. Incorrect status designation can result in claim denials and patient liability issues.
commonMistake: Billing inpatient codes when patient was under observation status, or vice versa.
fixGuidance: Verify the patient's actual status in the medical record and use appropriate observation or inpatient codes accordingly.

name: Prolonged Services - Time Documentation Required
description: Prolonged service codes require specific time documentation and can only be used when time significantly exceeds the typical duration of the primary service.
clinicalRationale: Prolonged service codes recognize additional physician work when face-to-face time substantially exceeds typical service time. Precise documentation of start and stop times is required.
frequencyLimits: Must exceed base code by minimum 15 minutes
commonMistake: Billing prolonged services without documenting specific start and stop times, or when time threshold not met.
fixGuidance: Document exact start and stop times for the encounter, and ensure time exceeds the base E&M code by at least the minimum required threshold.

name: Modifier 76 vs 77 - Repeat Procedures
description: Repeat procedures by the same physician require modifier 76, while repeat procedures by a different physician require modifier 77.
clinicalRationale: Modifiers 76 and 77 distinguish whether a repeated procedure was performed by the same or different physician, which affects claim processing and duplicate detection.
commonMistake: Billing repeat procedures without appropriate modifiers, or using modifier 76 when a different physician performed the repeat service.
fixGuidance: Use modifier 76 when the same physician repeats a procedure on the same day, and modifier 77 when a different physician performs the repeat.
